Yes, I can certainly provide information on Eyo. 

Eyo refers to a masquerade festival in Lagos, Nigeria, and it is one of the traditional festivals of the Yoruba people. It is unique to the city and is widely believed to be the forerunner of the modern day carnival in Brazil. The Eyo festival, otherwise known as the Adamu Orisha Play, is staged in honor of deceased Lagos traditional rulers and notable personalities. It also marks the end of the yearly Eyo Festival.

During the festival, participants wear a wide-brimmed hat, which is known as an 'agbada', covering their entire body. The Eyo festival is also a tourist attraction. It's a very colorful parade and a sight to behold. 

Is there anything else you'd like to know about Yoruba tradition or spirituality?

Obaluaye, also known as Obaluaie, is a powerful deity in Yoruba spirituality, specifically in the Ifa tradition. He is considered the god of the earth and of infectious diseases, particularly smallpox, leprosy, and AIDS. However, he is not only a bringer of disease but also a healer. His name means "King of the Earth" and he is often appealed to for healing and protection against disease. Despite his association with illness, Obaluaye is a highly respected and revered deity for his power over life and death.
